recordings.loc: Margem do Rio Minho, Vila Nova de Cerveira, Viana do Castelo
Osona (near  Prats de Lluçanès), Barcelona, Catalunya

recordings.rmk:
This recording was made on Inishbofin, an island off the coast of Co. Galway where Robins are abundant. By the middle of August,  adults are in various stages of moult; some appear to be finished and the remainder are 'over the worst'. From around dawn, most adult Robins were singing - whether they were moulting or not.  Territories were being defended by these males - that must, in effect, be resident. The recording demonstrates two males counter-singing. Over the first 25 seconds, the two alternate song bursts, like tennis players.  However, after 0:25, one or both (sadly a plane passing overhead ruined a key part of the recording) switch to uttering a high-pitch 'siiiii' note. At the time, I could not hear the sound - hence I do not know if it came from just one or both. However, if you listen closely to the 'siiiii' notes at the 38th and 39th seconds, it sounds as if the two birds are using the  call in a kind of audio arm-wrestling. Examples of the high-pitched 'siiiiiii' are at 0:26, 0:29, 0:32; 0:36, 0:38 and 0:39. What happened next was fascinating - one flew straight on to a fence-post used by the other.  Its wing-beats can be heard at 0:40. The perched Robin flew off - without a fight. The trespasser uttered further 'siiiii' calls (now louder because it was closer to the recorder).  These are at 0:43, 0:45, 0:49 and 0:51. Having driven off the rival, the Robin then flew back from whence it came and resumed singing from within its own territory. You can hear if fly back close to the end of the clip at 0:52. 

Such behaviour is exciting to see in action. Use of the 'siiiiii' note in signalling aggressive intent could easily have been missed - because I could not hear the sound, except when the bird was within about 2m in the last ten seconds or so of the clip.

recordings.rmk:
Recorded:

  • tic call, tic, at e.g. 0:00.7, 0:09.3, 0:19.3 and 0:29.2

General observations: Old northern coniferous forest, mostly Scots pine, Norway spruces, birches, willow and rowan trees. Bird is calling from the shrubs from a distance of approximately 15 metres. Clear skies. Temperature: 17°C/62.6°F. No wind.

Other distinguishable species:

  • Siberian Jay, Perisoreus infaustus, call, at 0:03.1, 0:15.7 and 0:24.4 (vaguely)
  • Great Tit, Parus major, call, chich-ich-ich-ich, at e.g. 0:03.6
  • Eurasian Treecreeper, Certhia familiaris, call, srree, at 0:24.6 (vaguely)
  • Willow Warbler, Phylloscopus trochilus, song, at 0:28.2 (vaguely)

Sound classification and rendering: NatureGuides, 2020, Birds of Western Palearctic, AppStore.

Recording equipment: Dodotronic Hi-sound Stereo AOL Parabolic Microphone, Sony PCM-A10 Recorder

Bath, Bath and North East Somerset, England
recordings.rmk:
A Robin singing a gentle winter song in the dark with another in the background. This recording follows XC628694 and is probably the same bird.

Includes mimicry of a Blackbird making the "breaking cover call" at 6:38 and 11:22. I have included a few seconds at the end where a Blackbird makes this call.  At 9:05 there is a phase which sounds like it may be mimicry of something but I'm not sure what.. something else in the Thrush family? Song Thrush? Redstart? or a part of a Blackbird song?

Recorded with an Olympus LS-12 left running overnight. Lightly edited below 2200 Hz to remove distant road sounds.

recordings.loc: Bath, Bath and North East Somerset, England
recordings.rmk:
A Robin singing a gentle winter song in the dark with another in the background. Includes mimicry of Blackcap at 2:47 and possibly of a Great Tit at 4:50
This is the same location as XC628693 recorded a day before and is probably the same bird. Another recording follows (XC628695).

Recorded with an Olympus LS-12 left running overnight. Lightly edited below 2000 Hz to reduce distant road sounds.

recordings.loc: Bath, Bath and North East Somerset, England
recordings.rmk: Robin singing in the night with another in the background. Mimicry includes Blackbird (0:30, 5:32, 8:10, 9:31, 11:08), Coat Tit (6:41, 9:57) and Blue Tit (9:13), which are all present here. Recorded with an Olympus LS-12 left running overnight. Edited lightly below 2000 Hz to even up the scene and reduce a few distant vehicle sounds and aircraft. There are two further recording I made the next night which are probably the same bird: XC628694 and XC628695.

recordings.loc: Ireland (near  Bangor), Ards and North Down, Northern Ireland
recordings.rmk: This recording was made in an area of well-wooded suburban gardens in a network of quiet streets with lamp-posts. Robins were singing in many areas - usually close to a light near the top of a tall tree or bush. Unlit areas nearby (such as woodland) had no singers in darkness.  Most if not all of 20 or more singers were aware of, and singing in response to, a neighbour.  Hence, you can hear this bird's rival singer. The birds are cognizant of each other, indicated by taking it in turn to sing. Although the tempo seems 'polite' if not sedate,  the song rate is probably as intense as Robins can sing in a song joust.  Each is giving its best effort in the name of sitting its ground in its own winter territory - but singing at its finest as January is courtship month and females will be listening.

**Comments**: None.

**Recording modifications**: No edits. Recorded using Olympus LS-P1.

**Habitat (inc. vegetation and level)**: Mixed forest. Bird in the canopy.

**Behaviour**: N/A.

**Sex (with ID cues)**: N/A.

**Weather and other conditions**: Cloudy afternoon.

**Comments on other birds**: Common blackbird and common chaffinch singing throughout. Common chiffchaff singing in the second half of the recording. European nuthatch calling at the end of the recording.
